body: The bank runs that regulators feared when they announced plans for an economic bailout in September brought to mind mobs of frantic customers swarming local banks, withdrawing all their deposits. But that terminology took on a different meaning on Monday when banks across New York City were deluged by abrupt withdrawals of another kind: robberies.
title: On a Single Day, Five Banks in the City Are Robbed, in Busy Areas and in Broad Daylight

body: CARS were moving in two directions last week on the stretch of Fulton Street in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, for the first time since a two-year construction project tore up the road and sidewalk and forced all traffic to flow one way. The effect of the construction on the businesses along the street was devastating, merchants said. Now, some are
title: FORT GREENE | CLINTON HILL; A Plan for Unity Sets Merchants at Odds

body: Looking Ahead ADAM PERRY LANG AND JAMIE OLIVER Adam Perry Lang, left, the chef and a partner in Daisy May's BBQ USA, and Jamie Oliver, the English celebrity chef, have teamed up with deep-pocketed backers to open a chain of restaurants. There is no name yet, but the first restaurant is to be in Dublin, with openings planned for Berlin, Cape Town
title: Off the Menu

body: DEAR DIARY: A few weeks ago I took my 12-year-old son, Joshua, to the Museum of Natural History. While we were waiting to get tickets, I pointed out the inspiring quotations by Theodore Roosevelt that line the upper walls of the Roosevelt Memorial rotunda. The one over the ticket counter concludes: ''Courage, hard work, self-mastery and intelligent
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: 'THE CHARLIE BROWN CHRISTMAS' Linus's grungy blanket, Charlie Brown's hairs, Lucy's attitude: the whole Peanuts gang will become three-dimensional this weekend when the young theater company Pig Brooch stages a verbatim re-enactment of ''A Charlie Brown Christmas,'' the perennial, and perennially beloved, TV special. ''Metaphorically, everyone has
title: Spare Times

body: On a Tuesday morning in late November, in the dark living room of a two-story brick home in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, an unwatched television momentarily blared out an advertisement for a news program. The news show's topic that day, to be tackled by a panel of experts, was how the debt of Detroit's big automakers might affect Wall Street. Seated at
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Loss of a Job Dashes a Working Man's Simple Dreams

body: Their eyes met over mashed potatoes. Consuela Lewis was plating up fried-chicken dinners as a volunteer for an organization in Anchorage that serves free meals to children. Then she spotted Jerry Sails. ''I was like, 'Who is this stud muffin?' '' Ms. Lewis remembers. When the cafeteria closed, Ms. Lewis, then 19, and Mr. Sails, then 29, hung around
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Love in Alaska, and Tough Sledding in New York

But what is probably news to many who live outside Brooklyn's borders (and inside
title: Spare Times

body: A New York City patrolman used his baton to sodomize a man in a subway station, and two complicit colleagues helped him cover it up, the Brooklyn district attorney charged on Tuesday as he unsealed indictments against three police officers. Using graphic detail, the district attorney described an attack that he said left the man, Michael Mineo,
title: Assault Inquiry Brings Charges For 3 Officers

body: DOPPELT--Minnie, of Whippany, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, died peacefully in her sleep Saturday December 6, at the age of 90. With her husband Jacob Doppelt, she was active in support of the Yeshivah of Flatbush, and served as President of its Ladies Auxiliary. She was a life member and officer of AMIT. She is survived by her brother, Rabbi Abraham
title: Paid Notice: Deaths DOPPELT, MINNIE

body: AROUND TOWN BOWIEBALL The economy is tanking, the winter doldrums are setting in, and the tourists and the family are descending, but don't let that bring you down: pull yourself up by your skinny jeans and hit BowieBall, a glittery, wild-haired, wild-eyed party in honor of the Thin White Duke, in all his gender-bending glory. Deryck Todd, an
title: Spare Times

body: A 20-year-old man has been charged with murder in the stabbing death of a New York City bus driver, the police said on Tuesday. The man, Horace D. Moore, of 1327 Park Place in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, told the police that he stabbed the driver, Edwin Thomas, 46, on Monday after an argument on the bus, said the chief police spokesman, Paul J.
title: Crown Heights Man Is Charged With Bus Driver's Murder

body: A New York City bus driver was fatally stabbed in Brooklyn on Monday after refusing to give a transfer to his assailant, who had not paid his fare, the police said. Witnesses said the killer jumped off the bus, slipped the hood of his black sweatshirt over his head and ran away. New York City Transit officials said it was the first slaying of a
title: Rider Fatally Stabs City Bus Driver and Flees

body: WOLIN--Rochelle. Beloved mother of Haley and Brian, devoted brother of Kenneth, adoring daughter of Theda and the late Marvin Spitz, indeared grandmother of Madison and Brett. Your courage and strength will live with us forever. Funeral today 11:30am, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WOLIN, ROCHELLE

body: In the heart of Midtown, a yearlong project to build a new subway entrance provides a nightly feast for sidewalk superintendents and urban archaeologists. During the day, at least on weekdays, much of the underground work at Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street is hidden by steel plates weighing more than two tons each. They are removed about 10 p.m.,
title: MIDTOWN JOURNAL; New Subway Entrance Opens Window to an Old, Coal-Heated New York

body: CHILDREN'S CENTER, NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY Patience and Fortitude, the serenely majestic lions who serve as sentinels at the New York Public Library, have recently acquired a host of animal neighbors. Residing inside the building, they include a fox with a luxurious tail, a brilliant blue bull, a cocoa-colored bear and an aardvark wearing glasses.
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: GAUJEAN--Dr. Max Pierre, died November 21, 2008. He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Dr. Emmelyne St. Germain Gaujean, their children: Max G. Gaujean, Nadine Gaujean, Natasha Gaujean-La Mar, and Martine-Pascale Gaujean May, his brother Gerard Gaujean, six grandchildren, extended family and friends. Dr. Gaujean was born June 11, 1929 in Croix
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GAUJEAN, DR. MAX PIERRE

body: The ''Living In'' column last Sunday about Marine Park, Brooklyn, misidentified the shopping center on Flatbush Avenue near Avenue U. It is Kings Plaza, not Kings Highway Shopping Center.
title: Correction

body: A Brooklyn variety-store owner was critically wounded during a shootout Monday night in which he shot and killed two robbers, the police said. The police said they thought the two dead men were armed and had attempted to rob the store, located at 1051 Nostrand Avenue, about 8:20 p.m. It was unclear who fired first, the police said. The store owner
title: 2 Robbers Killed in Shootout at a Brooklyn Store

body: MARINE PARK, a neighborhood of 21,500 people in southeast Brooklyn, shares its name and a boundary with the borough's largest park, a 798-acre mass that stretches to the marshes of Jamaica Bay. title: LIVING IN | MARINE PARK, BROOKLYN; Isolation Is Pretty Splendid

title: Watch Out for That Stick, Er, Fist: Professional Ice Hockey Bursts Into Brooklyn

body: International LEADERS MEET IN ADVANCE Of Economic Conference The Group of 20 finance ministers and central bankers met in Sao Paolo, Brazil, to lay the groundwork for a critical economic summit meeting in Washington next weekend. title: Inside the Times: November 10, 2008

body: 'BOO AT THE ZOO' You can do so much with pumpkins this season: cook them for soups and desserts, carve them into jack-o'-lanterns, decorate them for your stoop, even give them to your cats as toys -- that is, if you have really, really big cats. The Bronx Zoo does, and giving its creatures pumpkins (above, a black leopard) is one of the high points
title: Spare Times: For Children

Written and directed by Jennifer Goodlander, the show focuses on Putu, a tomboy, who is lost in the jungle with

body: Javier Ortiz rounded the corner from 79th Street onto Amsterdam Avenue at midday on Sunday and let out a groan. To his left, a vendor was selling gooey mozzarella-filled arepas. To his right, a row of blenders whipped fruit into froth. Mr. Ortiz knew what lay ahead. There would be overly solicitous masseuses. Someone would be hawking
title: Back Rubs? Check. Chickens? Not at These Fairs.

body: NOT long ago, the hipsters of Brooklyn looked down their pierced noses on Prospect Heights, a sleepy neighborhood of brownstones and tree-lined streets just north of Prospect Park. While the area had a diverse mix of white, African-American and West Indian residents, there was little beside Caribbean takeout joints and hole-in-the-wall barbershops
title: SURFACING; Adding to the Mix in Brooklyn

body: EVEN years ago, back when she rented in East Flatbush, Ismay Gardner knew she liked Canarsie, a quiet suburban community on Brooklyn's south shore with row upon row of detached houses and neat lawns. When she decided to buy a house, Canarsie was the first place she looked, and even when she moved -- twice -- it was within Canarsie. Now, Ms.
title: LIVING IN | CANARSIE, BROOKLYN; Homey, but No Haven From Hard Times

body: New York City Opera opened what is going to be a modest season, devoid of staged productions, with a very fine concert of notable 20th-century works at St. George Theater on Staten Island on Saturday night. title: MUSIC REVIEW | NEW YORK CITY OPERA; Feeling Modern, City Opera Starts an Itinerant Season

title: Take Half a Ton Of Beef...

body: Though more marine traffic crosses under it than under any other city drawbridge, most drivers who traverse the humble Pelham Bay Bridge in the Bronx barely take notice. This buff-and-blue span in Pelham Bay Park -- a heavily traveled approach to City Island -- is certainly not the bridge to nowhere. But it is only a bit player in the
title: Honors for Bridges Many Take for Granted

body: AROUND TOWN BROOKLYN BOOK FESTIVAL Tucked within the list of events planned for the more than 140 authors appearing at this Sunday's book festival is a little reading called ''Brooklyn's Own,'' featuring three authors who call the borough home. It is a testament to the vitality of the Brooklyn literary scene that the reading is not the signature
title: Spare Times

body: FIVE in the morning down at the deli, Knapp Street, Brooklyn, the smell of the tide coming in soft and funky over Jordan's Lobster Dock down the block. People stand in line for coffee, ice, a sandwich for later. There is nervous energy in the air, guys shuffling in boots and flip-flops. Here are rumpled fishing guides ripped from the womb of sleep
title: A Short Cast Away

body: Modeled on noir and executed on acid, ''Able Danger'' is a paranoid fantasy of geek superheroics that lunges desperately for political relevance. And while that objective is not entirely baseless, it might have been simpler to achieve had the movie's retro style and hammy acting not skewed more toward the past than the present. At the center of the
title: MOVIE REVIEW | 'ABLE DANGER'; A Conspiracy Theorist, Closing In on That Smoking Gun

title: Spare Times

body: Few immigrant groups are as closely identified with an occupational niche as Koreans with grocery stores. A new book, ''Ethnic Solidarity for Economic Survival: Korean Greengrocers in New York City,'' offers a look at the complex role that ethnicity plays in those mom-and-pop businesses, which have been engines of economic mobility and opportunity
title: CITY ROOM; In the Produce Aisle, Solidarity for Korean Grocers

body: Squeezing a large urban retail center onto a small, oddly shaped building site is almost never easy in New York, and the task can become particularly daunting when a prominent national retailer decides to make the center a home for its largest store anywhere. Such were the hurdles that had to be cleared at the 300,000-square-foot Triangle Junction
title: Big Stores in Odd Shapes Arriving in Brooklyn

body: Before attempting to adequately describe the self-contained world created by the tens of thousands of masqueraders who will participate in the annual West Indian American Day Carnival in Brooklyn on Monday, it is helpful to understand a couple of points. First, a coordinated group of people participating in the Caribbean-inspired event wearing
title: A Carnival Approaches, and the Sequins Fly

body: Flatbush Avenue pulses in the Brooklyn distance, but back here the vines are heavy with the bounty of late summer, a salsa-lover's harvest of organic plum tomatoes, jalapeños and habaneros, along with bulbous eggplants, purple-veined Swiss chard, cucumbers, celery (for bloody marys), spearmint, basil, and strawberries, lavender, sunflowers,
title: Out Back, an Urban Oasis

body: They are like extraterrestrial visitors in the tired streetscape, gleaming new stainless-steel-and-tempered-glass newsstands that carry grand lighted advertisements. They've been dropping onto the sidewalks of New York -- quite literally, as cranes swing them down from flatbed trucks. So far, 97 of 330 have been installed. But there have been
title: Newsstands of Tomorrow Get Mixed Reviews Today

body: FORGIVE us for asking, but what happened to August? (Wasn't it just May?) Politics happened, of course, and the Olympics, and a steady drumbeat of bad economic news played out from the deck of Time's winged chariot as it blistered past. Summer was fast this year, and now it's nearly over. It's Labor Day weekend, official last call for a family
title: What I Did This Summer. And You Can, Too.

body: The Alfa Romeo became a local icon, almost as familiar to the people who live on Plaza Street West as the sculpture of the horse-drawn chariot atop the arch at nearby Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn. The chariot is ridden by lady Columbia, heralded by two winged trumpeters. The aging Alfa was driven by Vincent Banescu, an elderly immigrant from
title: A Quiet Neighbor, a Fading Sports Car, and a Death Announced by Parking Tickets

body: NEXT weekend, according to nonpolice estimates, 10 quadrillion people will sweat their way down Eastern Parkway, dancing and eating and waving the flags of more than a dozen Caribbean nations during the city's most famous street party, the West Indian American Day Carnival. Into the food but not so much the ear-splitting music? Explore the West
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK | CARIBBEAN FOOD; In Brooklyn, Every Palate Is an Island

body: Detective Matthew Walker was sitting on his couch watching television recently when he saw surveillance video on the news of a man attacking an elderly woman from behind as she got off an elevator. The video, viewed by many people on the Internet and television since the police released it on Monday, has provoked widespread outrage. But for
title: Video of Attack In Brooklyn Leads to Arrest

body: The security camera inside the elevator captured it all: a vicious choke hold, an older woman's flailing arms and then her limp body sprawled on the floor as her attacker ran off with her purse. He even took the 85-year-old victim's cane. The attack on Thursday, captured on clean, crisp video at an apartment building in Flatbush, was the latest in
title: Video Shows An Attack In Brooklyn

body: ROSENBLATT--Minna, a leading figure among the first generation of antiques dealers responsible for the 1950s revival of Tiffany lamps and French, Austrian and American art glass from the Art Nouveau period died August 2nd at her country home in Walker Valley, New York. A resident of New York City, she was 94 and died of natural causes. A Brooklyn
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ROSENBLATT, MINNA

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: The large white bandage covering Enois Malbranche's right eye hid the hole left by a young woman in his taxi who had demanded his money, pointed a gun at his face and pulled the trigger. ''When you get shot, it's hot and you see the flash,'' Mr. Malbranche, 62, a yellow-cab driver for nine years, said from his bed at Kings County Hospital Center on
title: Cab Driver Recalls Shot Destroying His Right Eye

body: A police officer shot and killed a suspect in a stolen car on Thursday night in Brooklyn when the man tried to make a U-turn during a chase and hit the officer, whose gun accidentally discharged, the police said. The victim, a 25-year-old man, was struck from behind in the shoulder, the police said. He was driving a Ford Mustang that had been
title: Suspect in Stolen Car Hits Officer and Is Fatally Shot

body: STORMS can roll in quickly across Breezy Point, Queens, which sits on a low-lying spit at the borough's southernmost edge, dangling into the Atlantic Ocean. title: LIVING IN BREEZY POINT, QUEENS; Beach Living, 22 Miles From Manhattan

title: Brooklyn Boy, 11, Is Killed in a Hit and Run

title: In Heat Like This, a Little Off the Top Isn't Enough

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Prospect Heights is among the city's smaller neighborhoods, but it is home to numerous attractions (the Brooklyn Public Library, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Museum) and to a vibrant dining scene. There is room for the Garden Cafe, a tiny institution since 1986, and for James, a promising restaurant that opened last month. Abigail
title: GOOD EATING | PROSPECT HEIGHTS; A Tasty Density

body: For Siddiq Booker, life is full of rejections. Clutching a handful of CDs that bore his dreadlocked visage, Mr. Booker scanned Broadway's throngs of students, tourists and office workers for anyone he could stop long enough to buy his latest record, which is titled, fittingly, ''Hustle to Be Free.'' As sirens blared and cab horns honked past Eighth
title: On the Sidewalks, the Persistent Pitch of Rappers Peddling Their Own Voices

title: Spare Times: For Children

body: FOR CHILDREN 'CINDERELLA' (Saturday) Forget about a wicked stepmother and a pumpkin-turned-coach. This new production by Youth on Target Theater Company is drawn from the Italian tradition, in which Cinderella's mother is very much alive, and Cinderella is not so much persecuted as immobilized by grief. body: WITH a trunk full of cod, brisket, blackberries, arugula and antifreeze, Alan Harding drives down Smith Street, past American Apparel, past the Michelin-starred restaurant Saul and past Patois, the bistro he helped open 11 years ago. Back then the neighborhood was a more likely destination for drug deals than dinner. Patois, where he was the chef,
title: Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn

body: Farmhouse Food Before you scoff at the idea of a class in cooking over an open fire in early July, consider the summertime passion for grilling. But in the 19th century such cooking was different. Just how different will be demonstrated on Thursday by Carolina Capehart, a food historian, who will prepare johnnycakes and corn dodgers from 5 to 7
title: Calendar

body: The state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, said on Wednesday that his office had uncovered numerous instances of child care centers in New York City misspending public funds. title: State Finds Fund Misuse At 19 Child Care Centers

body: ON most summer Sundays, Brooklyn is burning. Smoke rises from grills, many of them charcoal-fueled, illegal and loaded with jerk chicken -- the spiced, smoky favorite of the borough's large Jamaican community. ''We don't mess around out here,'' said Hubert Lawton, an owner of Boston Jerk City in East Flatbush, where an oil drum full of charcoal
title: Sweet Heat: For Jamaicans, It's About Jerk

body: On Monday nights in Brooklyn, a band of Frenchmen and Americans play Peruvian music. ''I know that sounds a bit absurd,'' said Olivier Conan, lead singer of the band, Chicha Libre, whose name is a tribute to the craze for a style of music called Chicha that took root in the Peruvian Amazon in the early 1970s. ''But we take the music very seriously,
title: A Peruvian Sound in a Brooklyn Bar

body: EVER since 2003, when a leggy Muslim girl from Senegal named Hawa Kebe immigrated to Brooklyn, in the eighth grade, she has dreamed of going to her senior prom. So in the late fall, when she learned that her high school wasn't planning a prom, she volunteered to organize one. Never mind that many of Hawa's classmates at the International High
title: This Strange Thing Called Prom

body: It is a routine so ingrained in the New Yorker's life that it seems to have always existed: And on the sixth day, God created man. title: Where Parking Rules the Days, A Little Miracle

body: Even Kings and Queens are facing their own food crisis. Kings and Queens Counties, that is. title: CITYWIDE; The Lost Supermarket: A Breed in Need of Replenishment

title: Eyes on the Sky at the First Crane Jump Since a Collapse

body: Of Bikes and Railings Q. I see signs affixed to subway entrances that state that it is illegal to lock ''anything'' to the outside stair railings. title: F. Y. I.

body: IN 1963, when Jaime Debbah was 28 years old, he left his fiancée, his family and the close-knit Jewish community around Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn -- his entire world -- to go to East Africa. He took with him a bruised heart and an anxious mind, but a few weeks later, he returned, carrying a bagful of colorful beads and the makings of a new life.
title: UNION SQUARE; Mending A Heart, Finding A Calling

body: The growing possibility that much of the multibillion-dollar Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn will be scrapped because of a lack of financing may be a bitter pill for its developer, Forest City Ratner. title: ARCHITECTURE; What Will Be Left of Gehry's Vision for Brooklyn?

title: Slow Economy Likely to Stall Atlantic Yards

body: A deeply divided jury in Brooklyn convicted the stepfather of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown of first-degree manslaughter for his role in her fatal 2006 beating, inflicted as punishment for stealing a snack from the refrigerator and jamming his computer printer with toys. But the jury acquitted the stepfather, Cesar Rodriguez, of second-degree murder.
title: Stepfather Is Found Guilty In Death of 7-Year-Old Girl

author: The Brooklyn Philharmonic's John Corigliano festival ends on Saturday afternoon with a performance of his song cycle ''Mr. Tambourine Man'' by the soprano Amy Burton at the Brooklyn Public Library, Grand Army Plaza at Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway; BrooklynPhilharmonic.org, (718) 636-4100.
body: Ever since he became the Brooklyn Philharmonic's music director in 2005, Michael Christie has been intent on restoring the thematic programming -- and with it, the feeling that the orchestra's concerts were events -- that was the philharmonic's calling card through the 1990s. His program on Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music,
title: MUSIC REVIEW | BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC; Drama In Stories Written In Sounds

author: As told to Jennifer Bleyer
body: AS a child growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Robert Holt Jr. thought that the mysterious gray machines rolled into his school for Election Day looked like coffins. Now, as one of 21 repairmen in the place where Brooklyn's voting machines are fixed, he has developed a certain amount of affection for the hulking contraptions. Mr. Holt, 47, is a
title: THE VOICE; The Fixer

body: Before he became notorious for his anti-American and anti-Semitic ravings, and before he became an icon for dominating, and then dismissing, the cloistered world of chess, Robert James Fischer was just Bobby, another young New Yorker on the make. His world was the city, and friends say that before he made comments supportive of the 2001 World Trade
title: Fischer's Roots in City Tangle With His Legacy

body: AROUND TOWN MARTIN LUTHER KING'S BIRTHDAY The older a holiday is, the more ingrained its traditions. So it's no surprise that there is no time-honored way to observe a holiday first observed a little more than two decades ago. A day of mourning is a stretch, especially for those under 40, whose only image of Dr. King is of a man in grainy
title: Spare Times Listings

title: For Children

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites 'SCREEN TEST' For six years in the 1990s Rob Roth, a downtown video director and designer, promoted a ''cyber-fetish-nightlife spectacle'' called Click + Drag at the Chelsea club Mother. title: Spare Times

body: DANCE Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. AKIM FUNK BUDDHA (Friday through Sunday) Expect the sacred and the profane in Akim Ndlovu's new ''Fountain of Youth'' -- and pretty much anything else performed by his company. The piece examines weighty issues like fate, youth and love, but with spectacular visuals and a free-flight
title: Dance Listings

body: DANCE Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. RICHARD SIEGAL In 2004 Richard Siegal choreographed ''Stranger,'' a solo to be seen by a single spectator by appointment only. That viewer was led down a labyrinth of corridors at the Frankfurt Opera House, where Mr. Siegal was part of William Forsythe's Frankfurt Ballet. Then, in a
title: Dance Listings

body: By the time thousands of mourners gathered on Tuesday to say farewell to Lt. John H. Martinson, his fellow firefighters had already spent five days telling the world about his bravery, his willingness to run first into the flames and stay there until everyone had escaped, which is part of what led to his death last week at a smoky Brooklyn blaze.
title: Tributes and Grief at a Funeral for a Firefighter

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites BULL RIDING INVITATIONAL Some people do yoga. Some meditate. Paulo Crimber happens to still his mind while riding a 1,500-pound bull that's trying to throw him into a pit of hard-packed dirt in front of thousands of screaming spectators. ''I always try not to think too much,'' Mr. Crimber, one of several professional
title: Spare Times

body: SHERMAN--Arnold E. Beloved husband of Naomi S. Sherman. Loving father of William and Jane Sherman, Patty and Richard Rudolph, and Joseph and Lisa Sherman. Cherished grandfather of David, Michael, Jason, Vicky, Andrew, Sam and Nathan. Devoted brother of Florence Hartenstein and brother-in-law of Ruth Kotcher. Dear uncle, great-uncle and friend.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SHERMAN, ARNOLD E
